questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a 2-month history of persistent diarrhea, a worsening rash on his hands and neck, and episodes of memory lapses and confusion. His diet primarily consists of untreated maize (corn). Which vitamin deficiency is he most likely suffering from? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pellagra, caused by niacin deficiency, presents with a triad of symptoms: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. A diet primarily consisting of untreated maize can increase the risk of this deficiency.

questions.text: A medical student presented with complaints of repeated episodes lasting approximately 30 minutes, characterized by breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and a fear of an impending heart attack. The patient has experienced these episodes 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, and investigations did not reveal any obvious abnormalities. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Panic Disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack. Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques] is preferred.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

questions.text: Cannabinoids are not approved for treatment of ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rett syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In summary, cannabinoids, specifically cannabidiol (CBD), are not approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome, whereas they are approved for use in Dravet Syndrome, Tuberous Sclerosis, and Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of recurrent sinusitis presents with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever. A computed tomography (CT) scan was done. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent complications such as vision loss, intracranial spread of infection, and other severe outcomes.

questions.text: PQLI indicators include: (NEET PG 2024) Literacy rate Infant mortality rate Life expectancy at birth Income per capita
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) Only two of these

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PQLI measures the quality of life based on literacy rate, infant mortality rate, and life expectancy at age one, excluding income and life expectancy at birth.
  • ➤ Remember – PQLI range – 0 – 100 (India - 65)
  • ➤ Remember – PQLI range – 0 – 100 (India - 65)

questions.text: The most common triggering factor of the given condition is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common trigger for erythema multiforme , particularly when target lesions are present on the palms, is infection, notably with herpes simplex virus .
  • ➤ most common trigger
  • ➤ erythema multiforme
  • ➤ target lesions
  • ➤ palms,
  • ➤ herpes simplex virus
  • ➤ Additional information

  • ↳ Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9 th Edition volume I Chapter 4. Page no 4.11, 4.13

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulants requires coagulation profile monitoring? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lepirudin, a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, requires routine coagulation profile monitoring using aPTT to ensure therapeutic efficacy and safety.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs can increase glucose excretion in urine? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Empagliflozin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor .
  • • an SGLT2 inhibitor
  • • Drugs in this class (such as empagliflozin, canagliflozin, and dapagliflozin) inhibit the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine (glycosuria). This helps lower blood glucose levels.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Glimepiride: A sulfonylurea that stimulates insulin release from the pancreas.
  • • Option A. Glimepiride:
  • • Option B. Liraglutide: A GLP-1 receptor agonist that increases insulin secretion, slows gastric emptying, and promotes satiety.
  • • Option B. Liraglutide:
  • • Option C. Acarbose: An alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays carbohydrate absorption in the intestines, leading to increased excretion of undigested carbohydrates in the stools.
  • • Option C. Acarbose:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Empagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, increases glucose excretion in the urine by inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in the kidneys.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant patient presented with complaints of worsening of hearing since the onset of pregnancy. On PTA the following graph was obtained. Which of the following statements regarding the disease is true? (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained

options.label: B
options.text: Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

questions.correct_answer: D. Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient, being pregnant and experiencing worsening hearing loss, suggests otosclerosis. The provided PTA (Pure Tone Audiogram) shows a significant air-bone gap on the right side, indicating conductive hearing loss, which is consistent with otosclerosis.
  • • Definitely, air travel is contraindicated for patients post-stapedectomy for at least three months. The variations in middle ear pressure during ascent and descent can lead to displacement or dislocation of the prosthetic piston used in the surgery, making this statement true.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained: In otosclerosis, an As type of tympanogram (indicating reduced compliance of the middle ear system) is typically obtained, not Ad. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.
  • • Option A. Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained:
  • • Option B. Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss: A notch at 2000Hz on bone conduction is known as Carhart's notch, which is indicative of otosclerosis, not noise-induced hearing loss. Noise-induced hearing loss typically presents a notch at 4000Hz. Hence, this statement is incorrect.
  • • Option B. Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss:
  • • Option C. Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery: Ménière's disease is indeed a contraindication for stapes surgery. The presence of Ménière's disease can lead to complications such as irritation of the saccule during the surgery, causing vertigo and giddiness. Thus, this statement is false.
  • • Option C. Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Air travel is contraindicated for at least three months post-stapedectomy due to the risk of pressure-induced displacement or dislocation of the surgical prosthesis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient on cancer chemotherapy developed neutropenia. Which of the following drug is used to increase the immunity in this person? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Filgrastim

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Filgrastim is the drug used to increase immunity in patients with chemotherapy-induced neutropenia. It works by stimulating the production of neutrophils, thereby reducing the risk of infection. Other drugs like darbepoetin, oprelvekin, and iron dextran are used for different hematological conditions and do not directly increase neutrophil counts or improve immunity in neutropenic patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient, on treatment for infertility, came with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and mild vaginal bleeding. Her beta hCG level was 2800 mlU/mL. On ultrasound, a 3cm mass was seen in the left adnexa. It contained a gestational sac with no fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate management for this patient hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Single dose methotrexate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy, beta hCG levels < 5000 IU/L, gestational sac size < 3.5 cm, and no fetal cardiac activity, single-dose methotrexate is the most appropriate management option.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25 th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25 th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: Which of the following refractory condition is depicted in the figure. ( NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Astigmatism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Recognizing and understanding these refractive conditions is essential for early detection and management. Regular eye examinations are crucial, as they allow for the timely prescription of corrective lenses or other treatments. Each condition affects vision in a unique way, and understanding these differences is key in providing effective patient care and guidance.

questions.text: What procedures are carried out during Breast Conservation Surgery? ( INICET MAY 2023) Wide local excision Axillary node dissection Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery Post-operative radiotherapy is optional
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

questions.text: A person reported to OPD alongside his 32-year-old brother working in a factory. The brother was recently subjected to a test – Coproporphyrin in urine. The physician should suspect: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coproporphyrin in urine is an important screening test for lead poisoning, indicating exposure to lead, and should be followed by diagnostic tests to assess absorption.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffering from persistent fatigue and lymph node enlargement visits the outpatient department. Examination of his peripheral smear reveals the presence of smudge cells. To further establish a diagnosis, what additional investigations will you conduct? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flow cytometry is the primary diagnostic tool for confirming Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia, particularly in cases where smudge cells are identified on a peripheral smear.

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trichomonas vaginalis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichomonas vaginalis infection is characterized by foul-smelling, frothy yellowish-green discharge and a strawberry-like appearance of the cervix.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is? ( INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Dimercaprol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment of Acute Arsenic poisoning
  • ➤ Treatment of Acute Arsenic poisoning
  • ➤ Hemodynamic stabilization for significant GI losses (vomiting and diarrhea) Gastric lavage is done repeatedly with large amount of warm water and milk; Chelating Agents Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning There are three chelating agents useful in acute arsenic poisoning: British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.
  • ➤ Hemodynamic stabilization for significant GI losses (vomiting and diarrhea)
  • ➤ Gastric lavage is done repeatedly with large amount of warm water and milk;

Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.

Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.
  • ➤ Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning

Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.

questions.text: Egg shell calcification is seen in all the following, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Metastatic lymph node

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A ring of calcification at the periphery of a lymph node is known as eggshell calcification.
  • • While calcifications can occur in metastatic nodes, they usually do not form the classic eggshell pattern. Instead, calcifications in metastatic nodes are often more irregular or diffusely distributed.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Silicosis: This condition, often seen in individuals exposed to silica dust, can lead to eggshell calcification of the lymph nodes due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis.
  • • Option A. Silicosis:
  • • Option B. Sarcoidosis: Another granulomatous disease that can lead to eggshell calcification in lymph nodes as part of its systemic manifestation affecting the lungs and lymphatic system.
  • • Option B. Sarcoidosis:
  • • Option C. Post-radiation therapy lymph nodes: Radiation can induce changes in lymph node structure including calcifications, commonly in a peripheral pattern, as a late sequela of treatment.
  • • Option C. Post-radiation therapy lymph nodes:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eggshell calcification is a specific radiologic sign associated with certain granulomatous diseases and post-treatment changes but is not commonly seen in metastatic lymph nodes. It may be seen in:
  • ➤ Silicosis Sarcoidosis post-radiation therapy in lymph nodes post-ATT in lymph nodes in TB
  • ➤ Silicosis
  • ➤ Sarcoidosis
  • ➤ post-radiation therapy in lymph nodes
  • ➤ post-ATT in lymph nodes in TB

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Police not under rank of sub inspector

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Patient

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exceptions where onus of proof lies with accused:
  • ➤ Exceptions where onus of proof lies with accused:
  • ➤ RES IPSA LOQUITOR (the thing or action speaks of itself) Insanity: If the defendant wishes to claim that he/she is insane, and therefore not guilty, the defendant bears the burden of proving his/her insanity. 114-A CrPc: In a case of rape, where sexual intercourse by the accused is proved and the question is whether it was without the consent of the woman alleged to have been raped, the court shall presume that she did not consent. The accused will have to prove that it was with consent. Contributory Negligence: If a doctor wants to take the defense of contributory negligence, then he will have to prove that the patient was also negligent along with him.
  • ➤ RES IPSA LOQUITOR (the thing or action speaks of itself)
  • ➤ RES IPSA LOQUITOR
  • ➤ Insanity: If the defendant wishes to claim that he/she is insane, and therefore not guilty, the defendant bears the burden of proving his/her insanity.
  • ➤ Insanity:
  • ➤ 114-A CrPc: In a case of rape, where sexual intercourse by the accused is proved and the question is whether it was without the consent of the woman alleged to have been raped, the court shall presume that she did not consent. The accused will have to prove that it was with consent.
  • ➤ 114-A CrPc:
  • ➤ Contributory Negligence: If a doctor wants to take the defense of contributory negligence, then he will have to prove that the patient was also negligent along with him.
  • ➤ Contributory Negligence:

questions.text: A patient has Bilateral right sided loss of vision. What is the most likely site of lesion. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Understanding the visual pathway is critical for localizing lesions based on patterns of visual field loss. Lesions at different points along the visual pathway (e.g., optic nerves, chiasma, tracts, or radiations) will produce characteristic visual field defects. This knowledge is used to guide further diagnostic testing and management, which may include imaging studies like MRI or CT scans to visualize the lesion and determine its cause.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor that can be used for the treatment of ADHD? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reboxetine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that can be used off-label for the treatment of ADHD, although it is not the first-line treatment. Atomoxetine is the preferred NRI for ADHD, but in its absence, Reboxetine is the next best option among the given choices.

questions.text: You are a researcher studying global mortality rates, and you notice substantial differences in the age structures of various countries. Recognizing that direct comparisons could be misleading due to these differences, you explore methods to equalize or adjust the mortality data to get a more accurate comparative view. In your research, you come across the term "standardized age mortality ratio." Which of the following best describes this concept? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution

options.label: B
options.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution

options.label: C
options.text: Removal of bias due to different age group population in different countries

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate age structure of different countries

questions.correct_answer: A. Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The standardized age mortality ratio adjusts the death rate of a population to a standard age distribution, allowing for more accurate comparisons between populations with different age structures.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Types of Standardized Death Rates
  • ➤ Types of Standardized Death Rates
  • ➤ Direct standardization:
  • ➤ Direct standardization:
  • ➤ Method: Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied on a standard population Total expected deaths calculated Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate Feasibility: Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR) Availability of population in each age group
  • ➤ Method: Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied on a standard population Total expected deaths calculated Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate
  • ➤ Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied on a standard population Total expected deaths calculated Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate
  • ➤ Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied
  • ➤ on a standard population
  • ➤ Total expected deaths calculated
  • ➤ Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate
  • ➤ Feasibility: Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR) Availability of population in each age group
  • ➤ Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR) Availability of population in each age group
  • ➤ Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR)
  • ➤ Availability of population in each age group
  • ➤ Indirect standardization: Standardized mortality ratio (SMR): Is simplest and most useful form
  • ➤ Indirect standardization:
  • ➤ Method: Calculate expected deaths, assuming that study group experiences the death rates of a standard population Feasibility: Permits adjustment where age-specific rates are not available or are unstable because of small numbers Examples of indirect Standardization: Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) = Observed deaths/ Expected deaths × 100 Life Table Analysis Survival Analysis
  • ➤ Method: Calculate expected deaths, assuming that study group experiences the death rates of a standard population
  • ➤ Feasibility: Permits adjustment where age-specific rates are not available or are unstable because of small numbers
  • ➤ Examples of indirect Standardization:
  • ➤ Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) = Observed deaths/ Expected deaths × 100
  • ➤ Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) = Observed deaths/ Expected deaths × 100
  • ➤ Life Table Analysis
  • ➤ Life Table Analysis
  • ➤ Survival Analysis
  • ➤ Survival Analysis

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is seen in the baroreceptor reflex? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Negative feedback

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.
  • • Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels
  • • Fig : Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism
  • • Fig
  • • Fig : Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism
  • • Fig
  • • Increase in blood pressure → stimulates baroreceptors → Herring’s nerves → glossopharyngeal nerves → nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla → release glutamate and activate the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) → inhibitions of rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) which is the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart. Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Feedforward : Incorrect. Feedforward control involves responses that anticipate changes, typically without a direct sensor feedback component, which is not applicable to the baroreceptor reflex.
  • • Option A. Feedforward
  • • Option B. Positive feedback : Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies an initial stimulus, leading to an even greater response. In contrast, the baroreceptor reflex mitigates changes in blood pressure to restore equilibrium.
  • • Option B. Positive feedback
  • • Option D. Adaptive control regulation : Incorrect. While adaptive control involves adjustment based on feedback, it is more complex and typically involves adjustments over time to control parameters. The baroreceptor reflex specifically uses a simpler, direct negative feedback mechanism to quickly counteract changes in blood pressure.
  • • Option D. Adaptive control regulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The baroreceptor reflex is a prime example of a negative feedback mechanism in human physiology, crucial for maintaining stable blood pressure by counteracting deviations from an individual's normal blood pressure set point

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not involved in Th1 response? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) IL- 4

questions.text: Which of the following triad is seen after an acute attack of angle-closure glaucoma? ( INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vogt's triad

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vogt's triad in a patient with a history of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma can aid in rapid diagnosis and management of this potentially vision-threatening condition. It underscores the importance of timely intervention to preserve ocular health and prevent irreversible complications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about vitamin K? ( NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypercoagulability.

options.label: C
options.text: Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency.

options.label: D
options.text: Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables.

questions.correct_answer: C. Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to Vitamin K deficiency

questions.text: A patient had a history of hepatic dysfunction, and the physical examination finding of the eye is shown below. Which of the following is the best way for confirmation of the diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Liver copper levels measured from a liver biopsy are the most definitive and confirmatory test for diagnosing Wilson’s disease, especially when characteristic signs like Kayser-Fleischer rings are present.

questions.text: A 25 yr G2P1 presents with heavy bleeding at 32 weeks. On examination, there is hypotension. The abdomen is tender and fetal parts not palpable. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Abruptio placenta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the case of a 25-year-old G2P1 woman presenting with heavy bleeding at 32 weeks of gestation, several key clinical features point towards a diagnosis of abruptio placenta.
  • • Abruptio placenta, or placental abruption, is a condition where the placenta detaches from the uterine wall prematurely, leading to significant bleeding.
  • • The critical signs here are:
  • • Hypotension : This indicates significant blood loss, which can be seen in both placenta previa and placental abruption. Tender abdomen : The tenderness of the abdomen is a hallmark of placental abruption due to the irritation and inflammation caused by the bleeding and the detached placenta. Fetal parts not palpable : This is due to the tense and tender uterus, which is characteristic of placental abruption.
  • • Hypotension : This indicates significant blood loss, which can be seen in both placenta previa and placental abruption.
  • • Hypotension
  • • Tender abdomen : The tenderness of the abdomen is a hallmark of placental abruption due to the irritation and inflammation caused by the bleeding and the detached placenta.
  • • Tender abdomen
  • • Fetal parts not palpable : This is due to the tense and tender uterus, which is characteristic of placental abruption.
  • • Fetal parts not palpable
  • • Abruptio placenta - Immediate management (delivery) is crucial to prevent maternal and fetal complications.
  • • In contrast, placenta previa typically presents with painless bleeding, and the uterus is usually relaxed and non-tender. Placenta previa involves the placenta covering the cervical os, which can lead to painless bleeding without the tenderness seen in placental abruption.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Placenta previa : Usually presents with painless bleeding and a relaxed, non-tender uterus.
  • • Option A. Placenta previa
  • • Option C. Show : Refers to the passage of a small amount of blood or mucus plug as labor begins, which does not cause significant bleeding or abdominal tenderness.
  • • Option C. Show
  • • Option D. Rupture uterus : While it can cause significant bleeding and abdominal tenderness, it is less common and typically associated with a history of uterine surgery or trauma.
  • • Option D. Rupture uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bleeding in Pregnancy after 28 weeks à is due to APH
  • ➤ 2 MC causes are of APH are – Placenta Previa (Painless bleeding, nontender uterus) and Abruptio placenta (Painful bleeding, tense & tender uterus)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to you with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Consolidation in the lung, often due to pneumonia, is characterized by a homogenous area of increased density with air bronchograms on imaging, and presents with symptoms such as fever, breathlessness, and productive cough.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false for descriptors of central tendency? ( INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Mode is affected by extreme values

options.label: B
options.text: Mean is affected by extreme values

options.label: C
options.text: Median is calculated by overall observations

options.label: D
options.text: Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor

questions.correct_answer: A. Mode is affected by extreme values
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mode is affected by extreme values

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mode is not affected by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data. In contrast, the mean is affected by extreme values, and the median is a robust measure of central tendency that is calculated using overall observations.
  • ➤ The mode is not affected by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data.
  • ➤ In contrast, the mean is affected by extreme values, and the median is a robust measure of central tendency that is calculated using overall observations.

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true? (NEET PF 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

options.label: B
options.text: Small blood vessels are most radioresistant

options.label: C
options.text: Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.correct_answer: A. Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This statement refers to the Inverse Square Law, which states that the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. This means that as the distance from the radiation source increases, the intensity of the radiation decreases exponentially. This law is fundamental in radiation physics and is crucial for understanding radiation exposure and protection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Larger vessels are more radioresistant compared to smaller ones. The endothelial cells lining small vessels are more susceptible to radiation damage due to their relatively higher rate of proliferation.
  • • Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant:
  • • Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Rapidly proliferating cells are the most radiosensitive. Cells that are dividing quickly, such as those in the gastrointestinal tract, bone marrow, and reproductive tissues, are more susceptible to radiation damage because radiation primarily affects DNA during cell division.
  • • Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant:
  • • Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant: This is incorrect. The gastrointestinal (GI) tract, including the small bowel, is among the most radiosensitive organ systems in the body. This high radiosensitivity is due to the rapid turnover of the epithelial cells lining the GI tract.
  • • Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source, as described by the Inverse Square Law.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: As per the new guidelines of MTP Act, Medical termination of pregnancy can be done after 24 weeks for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Foetus malformation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the new guidelines of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, as amended in 2021, medical termination of pregnancy is permitted in India up to 24 weeks of gestation.
  • • Beyond 24 weeks , MTP is permissible in cases where there are documented substantial fetal anomalies or malformations . In such cases, the opinion of the state medical board is required to proceed with the termination.
  • • Beyond 24 weeks
  • • substantial fetal anomalies or malformations
  • • state medical board
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Rape: This option is incorrect because, while rape or sexual assault is one of the indications for MTP up to 24 weeks, it is not a specific indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.
  • • Option A. Rape:
  • • Option B. Contraceptive failure: This option is incorrect because contraceptive failure is a social indication for MTP up to 24 weeks, but it is not a specific indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.
  • • Option B. Contraceptive failure:
  • • Option D. Insanity: This option is incorrect as it is not mentioned as an indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.
  • • Option D. Insanity:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As per the new guidelines of the MTP Act in India, medical termination of pregnancy can be performed beyond 24 weeks of gestation only in cases of documented substantial fetal anomalies or malformations, and the opinion of the state medical board is required.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On examination, he is noted to have subcutaneous emphysema and decreased breath sounds on the right side. His vital signs are unstable. What is the immediate management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

questions.correct_answer: A. Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space is the priority to relieve trapped air and stabilize the patient before further interventions.
  • ➤ In cases of suspected tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space is the priority to relieve trapped air and stabilize the patient before further interventions.

questions.text: According to current recommended dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be of total energy intake: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) < 10%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be less than 10% of total energy intake.

questions.text: A lady presented to OPD with complaint of pain in the breast. On clinical examination cracks in the nipple were present and fluctuation was positive. Most likely diagnosis in this lady will be? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a breastfeeding woman with breast pain, cracked nipples, and a positive fluctuation test, the most likely diagnosis is a breast abscess. This condition is a complication of mastitis and requires appropriate management to prevent further complications.

questions.text: What blood group should be given to a patient with Bombay blood group? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bombay blood group (Oh phenotype) is extremely rare, and individuals with this blood type can only receive blood from another Bombay blood group donor due to the absence of the H antigen and the presence of anti-H antibodies.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis

options.label: B
options.text: Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium

options.label: D
options.text: Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.correct_answer: D. Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillus: Typically seen as septate hyphae with acute angle branching on histological stains such as GMS. Mucor and Rhizopus: Non-septate, broad hyphae with right angle branching, distinguishing them from Aspergillus. Fusarium: Requires culture for definitive identification, although morphologically similar to Aspergillus.
  • ➤ Aspergillus: Typically seen as septate hyphae with acute angle branching on histological stains such as GMS.
  • ➤ Aspergillus:
  • ➤ Mucor and Rhizopus: Non-septate, broad hyphae with right angle branching, distinguishing them from Aspergillus.
  • ➤ Mucor and Rhizopus:
  • ➤ Fusarium: Requires culture for definitive identification, although morphologically similar to Aspergillus.
  • ➤ Fusarium:

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman visits an infertility clinic. She has a regular 28-day cycle. How should she be evaluated? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Serum progesterone on day 21

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For a woman with a regular 28-day cycle, serum progesterone is typically measured on day 21 to assess for ovulation. Progesterone levels on day 21 of the menstrual cycle provide information about whether ovulation has occurred.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Day 21 Progesterone Measurement: In a regular 28-day cycle, day 21 corresponds to the mid-luteal phase, about 7 days after ovulation. Progesterone levels peak during this time, and values above 10 ng/mL are indicative of ovulation. Purpose: This test helps to determine if the cycles are ovulatory or anovulatory.
  • • Day 21 Progesterone Measurement: In a regular 28-day cycle, day 21 corresponds to the mid-luteal phase, about 7 days after ovulation. Progesterone levels peak during this time, and values above 10 ng/mL are indicative of ovulation.
  • • Day 21 Progesterone Measurement:
  • • Purpose: This test helps to determine if the cycles are ovulatory or anovulatory.
  • • Purpose:
  • • Other tests for ovulation:
  • • Other tests for ovulation:
  • • Basal body temperature: A biphasic temperature pattern suggests ovulation. Urinary LH kits (ovulation prediction kits): Ovulation occurs the day following the peak LH surge. Endometrial biopsy: This can provide histological confirmation of ovulation. Ultrasonography: Follicular tracking can visualize the growth and rupture of the follicle.
  • • Basal body temperature: A biphasic temperature pattern suggests ovulation.
  • • Basal body temperature:
  • • Urinary LH kits (ovulation prediction kits): Ovulation occurs the day following the peak LH surge.
  • • Urinary LH kits (ovulation prediction kits):
  • • Endometrial biopsy: This can provide histological confirmation of ovulation.
  • • Endometrial biopsy:
  • • Ultrasonography: Follicular tracking can visualize the growth and rupture of the follicle.
  • • Ultrasonography:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Serum progesterone on day 14: Measuring progesterone on day 14 is not useful as it corresponds to the follicular phase when progesterone levels are low and not indicative of ovulation.
  • • Option A. Serum progesterone on day 14:
  • • Option C. Serum LH on day 14: While an LH surge around day 14 can indicate impending ovulation, it does not confirm that ovulation has actually occurred.
  • • Option C. Serum LH on day 14:
  • • Option D. Serum LH on day 21: Measuring LH on day 21 is not useful for assessing ovulation, as LH levels peak around mid-cycle and are not elevated during the luteal phase.
  • • Option D. Serum LH on day 21:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a woman with a regular 28-day menstrual cycle, measuring serum progesterone on day 21 is the appropriate method to evaluate for ovulation, with levels above 10 ng/mL indicating that ovulation has occurred.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg435
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg435

questions.text: A patient came to hospital who has not eaten anything for 2 days. Which of the following tests will be positive?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Only 3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Prolonged fasting leads to ketonuria which can be detected by Rothera’s test i.e., test 3
  • • Prolonged fasting leads to ketonuria which can be detected by Rothera’s test i.e., test 3
  • • Rothera's test: Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulphate. Add a few drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside followed by 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube. Development of a purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine . Strip tests based on the same principle are also available.
  • • Rothera's test:
  • • purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine
  • • Other tests
  • • Other tests
  • • Test 1: Benedict’s test: To 5 mL Benedict’s reagent, add 0.5 mL urine. Boil for 2 minutes. Blue, green, yellow, orange or red precipitate indicate reducing sugars. Black colour (muddy brown) is seen if homogentisic acid is present. Disaccharides may be identified by alkali destruction test. As there is low glucose in blood and will not be excreted in urine. So It will be negative.
  • • Test 1: Benedict’s test:
  • • Blue, green, yellow, orange or red precipitate indicate reducing sugars.
  • • The urine of a patient with diabetic keto acidosis will give positive Benedict's test as well as Rothera's test. But in starvation ketosis, Benedict's test is negative, but Rothera's test will be positive.
  • • But in starvation ketosis, Benedict's test is negative, but Rothera's test will be positive.
  • • Test 2: S hows the heat coagulation test . The heat coagulation test is used to detect the presence of proteins in urine. Since proteins are generally conserved during fasting to protect muscle mass, this test will be negative, rather proteins will be conserved to protect muscles.
  • • Test 2:
  • • S
  • • hows the heat coagulation test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Prolonged fasting leads to ketosis, which can be detected by Rothera’s test (test 3), resulting in a positive result for ketone bodies in the urine.

questions.text: An HIV patient came to the clinic with a history of diarrhea. Stool microscopy showed the oocysts that were 4-8 µm in size. The image is shown below. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cryptosporidium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cryptosporidium oocysts are small (4-8 µm) coccidian parasites responsible for causing diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. They are identified in stool samples by their size and acid-fast staining properties.
